right.desc: Muhammad ibn Jābir al-Ḥarrānī al-Battānī was a founding father of astronomy.
right.name: albattani

right.desc: Frances E. Allen, became the first female IBM Fellow in 1989. In 2006, she became the first female recipient of the ACM's Turing Award.
right.name: allen

right.desc: June Almeida - Scottish virologist who took the first pictures of the rubella virus -
right.name: almeida

right.desc: Kathleen Antonelli, American computer programmer and one of the six original programmers of the ENIAC -
right.name: antonelli

right.desc: Maria Gaetana Agnesi - Italian mathematician, philosopher, theologian and humanitarian. She was the first woman to write a mathematics handbook and the first woman appointed as a Mathematics Professor at a University.
right.name: agnesi

right.desc: Archimedes was a physicist, engineer and mathematician who invented too many things to list them here.
right.name: archimedes

right.desc: Maria Ardinghelli - Italian translator, mathematician and physicist -
right.name: ardinghelli

right.desc: Aryabhata - Ancient Indian mathematician-astronomer during 476-550 CE
right.name: aryabhata

right.desc: Wanda Austin - Wanda Austin is the President and CEO of The Aerospace Corporation, a leading architect for the US security space programs.
right.name: austin

right.desc: Charles Babbage invented the concept of a programmable computer.
right.name: babbage

right.desc: Stefan Banach - Polish mathematician, was one of the founders of modern functional analysis.
right.name: banach

right.desc: Buckaroo Banzai and his mentor Dr. Hikita perfected the 'oscillation overthruster', a device that allows one to pass through solid matter. -
right.name: banzai

right.desc: John Bardeen co-invented the transistor -
right.name: bardeen

right.desc: Jean Bartik, born Betty Jean Jennings, was one of the original programmers for the ENIAC computer.
right.name: bartik

right.desc: Laura Bassi, the world's first female professor
right.name: bassi

right.desc: Hugh Beaver, British engineer, founder of the Guinness Book of World Records
right.name: beaver

right.desc: Alexander Graham Bell - an eminent Scottish-born scientist, inventor, engineer and innovator who is credited with inventing the first practical telephone -
right.name: bell

right.desc: Karl Friedrich Benz - a German automobile engineer. Inventor of the first practical motorcar.
right.name: benz

right.desc: Homi J Bhabha - was an Indian nuclear physicist, founding director, and professor of physics at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research. Colloquially known as 'father of Indian nuclear programme'-
right.name: bhabha

right.desc: Bhaskara II - Ancient Indian mathematician-astronomer whose work on calculus predates Newton and Leibniz by over half a millennium -
right.name: bhaskara

right.desc: Sue Black - British computer scientist and campaigner. She has been instrumental in saving Bletchley Park, the site of World War II codebreaking -
right.name: black

right.desc: Elizabeth Helen Blackburn - Australian-American Nobel laureate; best known for co-discovering telomerase.
right.name: blackburn

right.desc: Elizabeth Blackwell - American doctor and first American woman to receive a medical degree -
right.name: blackwell

right.desc: Niels Bohr is the father of quantum theory.
right.name: bohr

right.desc: Kathleen Booth, she's credited with writing the first assembly language.
right.name: booth

right.desc: Anita Borg - Anita Borg was the founding director of the Institute for Women and Technology (IWT).
right.name: borg

right.desc: Satyendra Nath Bose - He provided the foundation for Bose–Einstein statistics and the theory of the Bose–Einstein condensate. -
right.name: bose

right.desc: Katherine Louise Bouman is an imaging scientist and Assistant Professor of Computer Science at the California Institute of Technology. She researches computational methods for imaging, and developed an algorithm that made possible the picture first visualization of a black hole using the Event Horizon Telescope. -
right.name: bouman

right.desc: Evelyn Boyd Granville - She was one of the first African-American woman to receive a Ph.D. in mathematics; she earned it in 1949 from Yale University.
right.name: boyd

right.desc: Brahmagupta - Ancient Indian mathematician during 598-670 CE who gave rules to compute with zero -
right.name: brahmagupta

right.desc: Walter Houser Brattain co-invented the transistor -
right.name: brattain

right.desc: Emmett Brown invented time travel.
right.name: brown

right.desc: Linda Brown Buck - American biologist and Nobel laureate best known for her genetic and molecular analyses of the mechanisms of smell.
right.name: buck

right.desc: Dame Susan Jocelyn Bell Burnell - Northern Irish astrophysicist who discovered radio pulsars and was the first to analyse them.
right.name: burnell

right.desc: Annie Jump Cannon - pioneering female astronomer who classified hundreds of thousands of stars and created the system we use to understand stars today.
right.name: cannon

right.desc: Rachel Carson - American marine biologist and conservationist, her book Silent Spring and other writings are credited with advancing the global environmental movement.
right.name: carson

right.desc: Dame Mary Lucy Cartwright - British mathematician who was one of the first to study what is now known as chaos theory. Also known for Cartwright's theorem which finds applications in signal processing.
right.name: cartwright

right.desc: George Washington Carver - American agricultural scientist and inventor. He was the most prominent black scientist of the early 20th century.
right.name: carver

right.desc: Vinton Gray Cerf - American Internet pioneer, recognised as one of 'the fathers of the Internet'. With Robert Elliot Kahn, he designed TCP and IP, the primary data communication protocols of the Internet and other computer networks.
right.name: cerf

right.desc: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar - Astrophysicist known for his mathematical theory on different stages and evolution in structures of the stars. He has won nobel prize for physics -
right.name: chandrasekhar

right.desc: Sergey Alexeyevich Chaplygin (Russian: Серге́й Алексе́евич Чаплы́гин; April 5, 1869 – October 8, 1942) was a Russian and Soviet physicist, mathematician, and mechanical engineer. He is known for mathematical formulas such as Chaplygin's equation and for a hypothetical substance in cosmology called Chaplygin gas, named after him.
right.name: chaplygin

right.desc: Émilie du Châtelet - French natural philosopher, mathematician, physicist, and author during the early 1730s, known for her translation of and commentary on Isaac Newton's book Principia containing basic laws of physics.
right.name: chatelet

right.desc: Asima Chatterjee was an Indian organic chemist noted for her research on vinca alkaloids, development of drugs for treatment of epilepsy and malaria -
right.name: chatterjee

right.desc: Pafnuty Chebyshev - Russian mathematician. He is known fo his works on probability, statistics, mechanics, analytical geometry and number theory
right.name: chebyshev

right.desc: Bram Cohen - American computer programmer and author of the BitTorrent peer-to-peer protocol.
right.name: cohen

right.desc: David Lee Chaum - American computer scientist and cryptographer. Known for his seminal contributions in the field of anonymous communication.
right.name: chaum

right.desc: Joan Clarke - Bletchley Park code breaker during the Second World War who pioneered techniques that remained top secret for decades. Also an accomplished numismatist
right.name: clarke

right.desc: Jane Colden - American botanist widely considered the first female American botanist -
right.name: colden

right.desc: Gerty Theresa Cori - American biochemist who became the third woman—and first American woman—to win a Nobel Prize in science, and the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Cori was born in Prague.
right.name: cori

right.desc: Seymour Roger Cray was an American electrical engineer and supercomputer architect who designed a series of computers that were the fastest in the world for decades.
right.name: cray

right.desc: Leonardo Da Vinci invented too many things to list here.

right.desc: A. K. (Alexander Keewatin) Dewdney, Canadian mathematician, computer scientist, author and filmmaker. Contributor to Scientific American's 'Computer Recreations' from 1984 to 1991. Author of Core War (program), The Planiverse, The Armchair Universe, The Magic Machine, The New Turing Omnibus, and more.
right.name: dewdney

right.desc: Satish Dhawan - Indian mathematician and aerospace engineer, known for leading the successful and indigenous development of the Indian space programme.
right.name: dhawan

right.desc: Bailey Whitfield Diffie - American cryptographer and one of the pioneers of public-key cryptography.
right.name: diffie

right.desc: Edsger Wybe Dijkstra was a Dutch computer scientist and mathematical scientist.
right.name: dijkstra

right.desc: Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac - English theoretical physicist who made fundamental contributions to the early development of both quantum mechanics and quantum electrodynamics.
right.name: dirac

right.desc: Agnes Meyer Driscoll - American cryptanalyst during World Wars I and II who successfully cryptanalysed a number of Japanese ciphers. She was also the co-developer of one of the cipher machines of the US Navy, the CM.
right.name: driscoll

right.desc: Donna Dubinsky - played an integral role in the development of personal digital assistants (PDAs) serving as CEO of Palm, Inc. and co-founding Handspring.
right.name: dubinsky

right.desc: Annie Easley - She was a leading member of the team which developed software for the Centaur rocket stage and one of the first African-Americans in her field.
right.name: easley

right.desc: Thomas Alva Edison, prolific inventor
right.name: edison

right.desc: Albert Einstein invented the general theory of relativity.
right.name: einstein

right.desc: Alexandra Asanovna Elbakyan (Russian: Алекса́ндра Аса́новна Элбакя́н) is a Kazakhstani graduate student, computer programmer, internet pirate in hiding, and the creator of the site Sci-Hub. Nature has listed her in 2016 in the top ten people that mattered in science, and Ars Technica has compared her to Aaron Swartz. -
right.name: elbakyan

right.desc: Taher A. ElGamal - Egyptian cryptographer best known for the ElGamal discrete log cryptosystem and the ElGamal digital signature scheme.
right.name: elgamal

right.desc: Gertrude Elion - American biochemist, pharmacologist and the 1988 recipient of the Nobel Prize in Medicine -
right.name: elion

right.desc: James Henry Ellis - British engineer and cryptographer employed by the GCHQ. Best known for conceiving for the first time, the idea of public-key cryptography.
right.name: ellis

right.desc: Douglas Engelbart gave the mother of all demos:
right.name: engelbart

right.desc: Euclid invented geometry.
right.name: euclid

right.desc: Leonhard Euler invented large parts of modern mathematics.
right.name: euler

right.desc: Michael Faraday - British scientist who contributed to the study of electromagnetism and electrochemistry.
right.name: faraday

right.desc: Horst Feistel - German-born American cryptographer who was one of the earliest non-government researchers to study the design and theory of block ciphers. Co-developer of DES and Lucifer. Feistel networks, a symmetric structure used in the construction of block ciphers are named after him.
right.name: feistel

right.desc: Pierre de Fermat pioneered several aspects of modern mathematics.
right.name: fermat

right.desc: Enrico Fermi invented the first nuclear reactor.
right.name: fermi

right.desc: Richard Feynman was a key contributor to quantum mechanics and particle physics.
right.name: feynman

right.desc: Benjamin Franklin is famous for his experiments in electricity and the invention of the lightning rod.
right.name: franklin

right.desc: Yuri Alekseyevich Gagarin - Soviet pilot and cosmonaut, best known as the first human to journey into outer space.
right.name: gagarin

right.desc: Galileo was a founding father of modern astronomy, and faced politics and obscurantism to establish scientific truth.
right.name: galileo

right.desc: Évariste Galois - French mathematician whose work laid the foundations of Galois theory and group theory, two major branches of abstract algebra, and the subfield of Galois connections, all while still in his late teens.
right.name: galois

right.desc: Kadambini Ganguly - Indian physician, known for being the first South Asian female physician, trained in western medicine, to graduate in South Asia.
right.name: ganguly

right.desc: William Henry 'Bill' Gates III is an American business magnate, philanthropist, investor, computer programmer, and inventor.
right.name: gates

right.desc: Johann Carl Friedrich Gauss - German mathematician who made significant contributions to many fields, including number theory, algebra, statistics, analysis, differential geometry, geodesy, geophysics, mechanics, electrostatics, magnetic fields, astronomy, matrix theory, and optics.
right.name: gauss

right.desc: Marie-Sophie Germain - French mathematician, physicist and philosopher. Known for her work on elasticity theory, number theory and philosophy.
right.name: germain

right.desc: Adele Goldberg, was one of the designers and developers of the Smalltalk language.
right.name: goldberg

right.desc: Adele Goldstine, born Adele Katz, wrote the complete technical description for the first electronic digital computer, ENIAC.
right.name: goldstine

right.desc: Shafi Goldwasser is a computer scientist known for creating theoretical foundations of modern cryptography. Winner of 2012 ACM Turing Award.
right.name: goldwasser

right.desc: Jane Goodall - British primatologist, ethologist, and anthropologist who is considered to be the world's foremost expert on chimpanzees -
right.name: goodall

right.desc: Stephen Jay Gould was was an American paleontologist, evolutionary biologist, and historian of science. He is most famous for the theory of punctuated equilibrium -
right.name: gould

right.desc: Carolyn Widney Greider - American molecular biologist and joint winner of the 2009 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine for the discovery of telomerase.
right.name: greider

right.desc: Alexander Grothendieck - German-born French mathematician who became a leading figure in the creation of modern algebraic geometry.
right.name: grothendieck

right.name: haibt

right.name: hamilton

right.desc: Caroline Harriet Haslett - English electrical engineer, electricity industry administrator and champion of women's rights. Co-author of British Standard 1363 that specifies AC power plugs and sockets used across the United Kingdom (which is widely considered as one of the safest designs).
right.name: haslett

right.desc: Stephen Hawking pioneered the field of cosmology by combining general relativity and quantum mechanics.
right.name: hawking

right.desc: Martin Edward Hellman - American cryptologist, best known for his invention of public-key cryptography in co-operation with Whitfield Diffie and Ralph Merkle.

right.desc: Werner Heisenberg was a founding father of quantum mechanics.
right.name: heisenberg

right.desc: Grete Hermann was a German philosopher noted for her philosophical work on the foundations of quantum mechanics.

right.desc: Caroline Lucretia Herschel - German astronomer and discoverer of several comets.

right.desc: Heinrich Rudolf Hertz - German physicist who first conclusively proved the existence of the electromagnetic waves.

right.desc: Jaroslav Heyrovský was the inventor of the polarographic method, father of the electroanalytical method, and recipient of the Nobel Prize in 1959. His main field of work was polarography.

right.desc: Dorothy Hodgkin was a British biochemist, credited with the development of protein crystallography. She was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964.
right.name: hodgkin

right.desc: Douglas R. Hofstadter is an American professor of cognitive science and author of the Pulitzer Prize and American Book Award-winning work Goedel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid in 1979. A mind-bending work which coined Hofstadter's Law: 'It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law.'
right.name: hofstadter

right.desc: Erna Schneider Hoover revolutionized modern communication by inventing a computerized telephone switching method.
right.name: hoover

right.desc: Grace Hopper developed the first compiler for a computer programming language and  is credited with popularizing the term 'debugging' for fixing computer glitches.
right.name: hopper

right.desc: Frances Hugle, she was an American scientist, engineer, and inventor who contributed to the understanding of semiconductors, integrated circuitry, and the unique electrical principles of microscopic materials.
right.name: hugle

right.desc: Hypatia - Greek Alexandrine Neoplatonist philosopher in Egypt who was one of the earliest mothers of mathematics -
right.name: hypatia

right.name: ishizaka

right.desc: Mary Jackson, American mathematician and aerospace engineer who earned the highest title within NASA's engineering department -
right.name: jackson

right.desc: Yeong-Sil Jang was a Korean scientist and astronomer during the Joseon Dynasty; he invented the first metal printing press and water gauge.
right.name: jang

right.name: jemison

right.desc: Betty Jennings - one of the original programmers of the ENIAC.
right.name: jennings

right.desc: Mary Lou Jepsen, was the founder and chief technology officer of One Laptop Per Child (OLPC), and the founder of Pixel Qi.

He was best known as host of the popular and long-running Russian scientific TV show, Evident, but Incredible. His father was the Nobel laureate Soviet-era physicist Pyotr Kapitsa, and his brother was the geographer and Antarctic explorer Andrey Kapitsa. -

right.name: kare

right.name: keldysh

right.desc: Mary Kenneth Keller, Sister Mary Kenneth Keller became the first American woman to earn a PhD in Computer Science in 1965.
right.name: keller

right.desc: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer known for his three laws of planetary motion -
right.name: kepler

right.desc: Omar Khayyam - Persian mathematician, astronomer and poet. Known for his work on the classification and solution of cubic equations, for his contribution to the understanding of Euclid's fifth postulate and for computing the length of a year very accurately.

right.desc: Sophie Kowalevski - Russian mathematician responsible for important original contributions to analysis, differential equations and mechanics -
right.name: kowalevski

right.desc: Marie-Jeanne de Lalande - French astronomer, mathematician and cataloguer of stars -
right.name: lalande

right.desc: Hedy Lamarr - Actress and inventor. The principles of her work are now incorporated into modern Wi-Fi, CDMA and Bluetooth technology.
right.name: lamarr

right.desc: Leslie B. Lamport - American computer scientist. Lamport is best known for his seminal work in distributed systems and was the winner of the 2013 Turing Award.
right.name: lamport

right.desc: Mary Leakey - British paleoanthropologist who discovered the first fossilized Proconsul skull -

right.desc: Henrietta Swan Leavitt - she was an American astronomer who discovered the relation between the luminosity and the period of Cepheid variable stars.

right.desc: Inge Lehmann - Danish seismologist and geophysicist. Known for discovering in 1936 that the Earth has a solid inner core inside a molten outer core.
right.name: lehmann

right.desc: Auguste and Louis Lumière - the first filmmakers in history -

right.name: mendel

right.name: proskuriakova

right.name: montalcini

right.desc: Rosalind Franklin - British biophysicist and X-ray crystallographer whose research was critical to the understanding of DNA -
right.name: rosalind

right.desc: Vera Rubin - American astronomer who pioneered work on galaxy rotation rates.
right.name: rubin

right.desc: Meghnad Saha - Indian astrophysicist best known for his development of the Saha equation, used to describe chemical and physical conditions in stars -
right.name: saha

right.desc: Jean E. Sammet developed FORMAC, the first widely used computer language for symbolic manipulation of mathematical formulas.
right.name: sammet

right.desc: Mildred Sanderson - American mathematician best known for Sanderson's theorem concerning modular invariants.
right.name: sanderson

right.desc: Satoshi Nakamoto is the name used by the unknown person or group of people who developed bitcoin, authored the bitcoin white paper, and created and deployed bitcoin's original reference implementation.
right.name: satoshi

right.desc: Adi Shamir - Israeli cryptographer whose numerous inventions and contributions to cryptography include the Ferge Fiat Shamir identification scheme, the Rivest Shamir Adleman (RSA) public-key cryptosystem, the Shamir's secret sharing scheme, the breaking of the Merkle-Hellman cryptosystem, the TWINKLE and TWIRL factoring devices and the discovery of differential cryptanalysis (with Eli Biham).
right.name: shamir

right.desc: Claude Shannon - The father of information theory and founder of digital circuit design theory. (
right.name: shannon

right.desc: Carol Shaw - Originally an Atari employee, Carol Shaw is said to be the first female video game designer.
right.name: shaw

right.desc: Dame Stephanie "Steve" Shirley - Founded a software company in 1962 employing women working from home.
right.name: shirley

right.desc: William Shockley co-invented the transistor -
right.name: shockley

right.desc: Lina Solomonovna Stern (or Shtern; Russian: Лина Соломоновна Штерн; 26 August 1878 – 7 March 1968) was a Soviet biochemist, physiologist and humanist whose medical discoveries saved thousands of lives at the fronts of World War II. She is best known for her pioneering work on blood–brain barrier, which she described as hemato-encephalic barrier in 1921.
right.name: shtern

right.desc: Françoise Barré-Sinoussi - French virologist and Nobel Prize Laureate in Physiology or Medicine; her work was fundamental in identifying HIV as the cause of AIDS.
right.name: sinoussi

right.desc: Betty Snyder - one of the original programmers of the ENIAC.
right.name: snyder

right.desc: Cynthia Solomon - Pioneer in the fields of artificial intelligence, computer science and educational computing. Known for creation of Logo, an educational programming language.
right.name: solomon

right.desc: Frances Spence - one of the original programmers of the ENIAC.
right.name: spence

right.desc: Michael Stonebraker is a database research pioneer and architect of Ingres, Postgres, VoltDB and SciDB. Winner of 2014 ACM Turing Award.
right.name: stonebraker

right.desc: Ivan Edward Sutherland - American computer scientist and Internet pioneer, widely regarded as the father of computer graphics.
right.name: sutherland

right.desc: Janese Swanson (with others) developed the first of the Carmen Sandiego games. She went on to found Girl Tech.
right.name: swanson

right.desc: Aaron Swartz was influential in creating RSS, Markdown, Creative Commons, Reddit, and much of the internet as we know it today. He was devoted to freedom of information on the web.
right.name: swartz

right.desc: Bertha Swirles was a theoretical physicist who made a number of contributions to early quantum theory.
right.name: swirles

right.desc: Helen Brooke Taussig - American cardiologist and founder of the field of paediatric cardiology.
right.name: taussig

right.desc: Valentina Tereshkova is a Russian engineer, cosmonaut and politician. She was the first woman to fly to space in 1963. In 2013, at the age of 76, she offered to go on a one-way mission to Mars.
right.name: tereshkova

right.desc: Nikola Tesla invented the AC electric system and every gadget ever used by a James Bond villain.
right.name: tesla

right.desc: Marie Tharp - American geologist and oceanic cartographer who co-created the first scientific map of the Atlantic Ocean floor. Her work led to the acceptance of the theories of plate tectonics and continental drift.
right.name: tharp

right.desc: Ken Thompson - co-creator of UNIX and the C programming language -
right.name: thompson

right.desc: Linus Torvalds invented Linux and Git.
right.name: torvalds

right.desc: Youyou Tu - Chinese pharmaceutical chemist and educator known for discovering artemisinin and dihydroartemisinin, used to treat malaria, which has saved millions of lives. Joint winner of the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
right.name: tu

right.desc: Alan Turing was a founding father of computer science.
right.name: turing

right.desc: Varahamihira - Ancient Indian mathematician who discovered trigonometric formulae during 505-587 CE -
right.name: varahamihira

right.desc: Dorothy Vaughan was a NASA mathematician and computer programmer on the SCOUT launch vehicle program that put America's first satellites into space -
right.name: vaughan

right.desc: Sir Mokshagundam Visvesvaraya - is a notable Indian engineer.  He is a recipient of the Indian Republic's highest honour, the Bharat Ratna, in 1955. On his birthday, 15 September is celebrated as Engineer's Day in India in his memory -
right.name: visvesvaraya

right.desc: Christiane Nüsslein-Volhard - German biologist, won Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1995 for research on the genetic control of embryonic development.
right.name: volhard

right.desc: Cédric Villani - French mathematician, won Fields Medal, Fermat Prize and Poincaré Price for his work in differential geometry and statistical mechanics.
right.name: villani

right.desc: Marlyn Wescoff - one of the original programmers of the ENIAC.
right.name: wescoff

right.desc: Sylvia B. Wilbur - British computer scientist who helped develop the ARPANET, was one of the first to exchange email in the UK and a leading researcher in computer-supported collaborative work.
right.name: wilbur

right.desc: Andrew Wiles - Notable British mathematician who proved the enigmatic Fermat's Last Theorem -
right.name: wiles

right.desc: Roberta Williams, did pioneering work in graphical adventure games for personal computers, particularly the King's Quest series.
right.name: williams

right.desc: Malcolm John Williamson - British mathematician and cryptographer employed by the GCHQ. Developed in 1974 what is now known as Diffie-Hellman key exchange (Diffie and Hellman first published the scheme in 1976).
right.name: williamson

right.desc: Sophie Wilson designed the first Acorn Micro-Computer and the instruction set for ARM processors.
right.name: wilson

right.desc: Jeannette Wing - co-developed the Liskov substitution principle. -
right.name: wing

right.desc: Steve Wozniak invented the Apple I and Apple II.
right.name: wozniak

right.desc: The Wright brothers, Orville and Wilbur - credited with inventing and building the world's first successful airplane and making the first controlled, powered and sustained heavier-than-air human flight -
right.name: wright

right.desc: Chien-Shiung Wu - Chinese-American experimental physicist who made significant contributions to nuclear physics.
right.name: wu

right.desc: Rosalyn Sussman Yalow - Rosalyn Sussman Yalow was an American medical physicist, and a co-winner of the 1977 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for development of the radioimmunoassay technique.
right.name: yalow

right.desc: Ada Yonath - an Israeli crystallographer, the first woman from the Middle East to win a Nobel prize in the sciences.
right.name: yonath

right.desc: Nikolay Yegorovich Zhukovsky (Russian: Никола́й Его́рович Жуко́вский, January 17 1847 – March 17, 1921) was a Russian scientist, mathematician and engineer, and a founding father of modern aero- and hydrodynamics. Whereas contemporary scientists scoffed at the idea of human flight, Zhukovsky was the first to undertake the study of airflow. He is often called the Father of Russian Aviation.
right.name: zhukovsky
